es.cpp_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of C++, a powerful extension of C. Master modern features to create versatile programs.
es.cpp_lesson2_course_description: Learn object-oriented programming with C++ classes. Master inheritance, templates, and smart pointers.
es.cpp_lesson3_course_description: Learn modern C++ features including smart pointers, move semantics, and STL algorithms.
es.cpp_lesson4_course_description: Master STL algorithms and C++17 features. Write efficient and expressive code.
es.cpp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
C++ is a powerful and fast programming language based on C with many additional features.

Like a sports car compared to a regular car - same speed but with more features!

Used in games, browsers (Chrome, Firefox), and 3D graphics software where speed matters.
es.cpp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are named 'boxes' that store data in your program.

Just like labeling toy boxes 'blocks' or 'dolls', we name variables to know what's inside.
es.cpp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Computers can calculate much faster than humans.

They never get tired, even with millions of calculations!
es.cpp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
The % operator gives you the remainder of division.

10 cookies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 left over!
es.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content:
Use += to add to current value and save it.

int x = 10;
x += 5;  // same as x = x + 5
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 15
es.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content:
Use -= to subtract and save:

int x = 10;
x -= 3;  // same as x = x - 3
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 7
es.cpp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: Combine text and variables in a single message using << like train cars connecting together.
es.cpp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
A dynamic array can grow or shrink as needed.

Like expandable lockers that can add more compartments when needed!
es.cpp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

'If it rains, bring umbrella'
'If sunny, play outside'
'If score >= 80, get a reward'
es.cpp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles when the condition isn't met.

Like 'If score >= 80, play games. Otherwise, study.'
es.cpp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
Combine multiple conditions:

&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true
es.cpp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Like taking attendance - calling each name one by one.
es.cpp_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
A dictionary (map) stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up a name to get the number!
es.cpp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Functions package reusable code with a name.

'Morning routine' = wash face + brush teeth + change clothes. Just say 'do morning routine'!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex1_comment1: Use class to define a class
es.cpp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
A class is a 'blueprint' that bundles data (variables) and functions together.

Like a 'Dog' blueprint with data (name, age) and functions (bark, run).
es.cpp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
A constructor is a special function that runs automatically when an object is created.

Like initial setup when you buy a new phone!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: Member functions are functions defined inside a class. They can use the class's data.
es.cpp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: A reference is an alias (another name) for an existing variable.
es.cpp_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets you create a new class based on an existing one.

'Dog' inherits from 'Animal' - gets eat() and sleep() for free!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Override lets you replace a parent class's function in the child class. Use virtual in the parent.
es.cpp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
Templates let you write generic code that works with any type.

One code works for int, double, string, and more!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions create anonymous functions on the spot.

Perfect for short, one-time-use functions!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Smart pointers automatically free memory when done.

Like an auto-return library book system - no memory leaks!
es.cpp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Exception handling lets you deal with errors gracefully.

Like a safety net in a circus - catch errors before they crash!
es.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
auto lets the compiler automatically determine the type.

auto x = 42;        // int
auto pi = 3.14;     // double
auto name = "Alice"; // const char*
es.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content:
NULL is actually 0, which can be ambiguous:

void f(int);    // takes int
void f(int*);   // takes pointer

f(NULL);    // Ambiguous!
f(nullptr); // Clearly f(int*)
es.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
const: value won't change after initialization
constexpr: value is known at compile time

const int a = getValue();     // OK at runtime
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // Must be compile-time
es.cpp_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
{} prevents data loss:

int x = 3.14;   // OK (becomes 3)
int z{3.14};    // Error! Narrowing conversion
es.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);
// More efficient than: shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
es.cpp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content:
array<int, 3> arr = {10, 20, 30};

arr.at(1);   // OK: 20
arr.at(10);  // Error! Out of range
arr[10];     // Undefined behavior (dangerous)
es.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content:
Capture lets lambdas use external variables.

int x = 10;
auto f = [x]() { return x * 2; };  // Capture by copy
auto g = [&x]() { x++; };           // Capture by reference
es.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content:
[x]      // Capture x by copy
[&x]     // Capture x by reference
[=]      // Capture all by copy
[&]      // Capture all by reference
[=, &x]  // All by copy, x by reference
es.cpp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
unique_ptr is an exclusive ownership smart pointer.

Like a movie ticket - only one person can hold it!

auto p = make_unique<int>(42);
cout << *p << endl; // 42
es.cpp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
variant safely holds one of several types.

variant<int, string> v;
v = 42;        // Now holds int
v = "hello";   // Now holds string
es.cpp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
Works with any string type, no copying:

void f(string_view sv);  // Recommended!

f(s);        // string
f("hello");  // literal
f(cstr);     // const char*
es.cpp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
Common exception types:

runtime_error     // Runtime error
logic_error       // Logic error
out_of_range      // Index out of bounds
invalid_argument  // Invalid argument

sv.cpp_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of C++, a powerful extension of C. Master modern features to create versatile programs.
sv.cpp_lesson2_course_description: Learn object-oriented programming with C++ classes. Master inheritance, templates, and smart pointers.
sv.cpp_lesson3_course_description: Learn modern C++ features including smart pointers, move semantics, and STL algorithms.
sv.cpp_lesson4_course_description: Master STL algorithms and C++17 features. Write efficient and expressive code.
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
C++ is a powerful and fast programming language based on C with many additional features.

Like a sports car compared to a regular car - same speed but with more features!

Used in games, browsers (Chrome, Firefox), and 3D graphics software where speed matters.
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are named 'boxes' that store data in your program.

Just like labeling toy boxes 'blocks' or 'dolls', we name variables to know what's inside.
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Computers can calculate much faster than humans.

They never get tired, even with millions of calculations!
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
The % operator gives you the remainder of division.

10 cookies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 left over!
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content:
Use += to add to current value and save it.

int x = 10;
x += 5;  // same as x = x + 5
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 15
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content:
Use -= to subtract and save:

int x = 10;
x -= 3;  // same as x = x - 3
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 7
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: Combine text and variables in a single message using << like train cars connecting together.
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
A dynamic array can grow or shrink as needed.

Like expandable lockers that can add more compartments when needed!
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

'If it rains, bring umbrella'
'If sunny, play outside'
'If score >= 80, get a reward'
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles when the condition isn't met.

Like 'If score >= 80, play games. Otherwise, study.'
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
Combine multiple conditions:

&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Like taking attendance - calling each name one by one.
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
A dictionary (map) stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up a name to get the number!
sv.cpp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Functions package reusable code with a name.

'Morning routine' = wash face + brush teeth + change clothes. Just say 'do morning routine'!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex1_comment1: Use class to define a class
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
A class is a 'blueprint' that bundles data (variables) and functions together.

Like a 'Dog' blueprint with data (name, age) and functions (bark, run).
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
A constructor is a special function that runs automatically when an object is created.

Like initial setup when you buy a new phone!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: Member functions are functions defined inside a class. They can use the class's data.
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: A reference is an alias (another name) for an existing variable.
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets you create a new class based on an existing one.

'Dog' inherits from 'Animal' - gets eat() and sleep() for free!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Override lets you replace a parent class's function in the child class. Use virtual in the parent.
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
Templates let you write generic code that works with any type.

One code works for int, double, string, and more!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions create anonymous functions on the spot.

Perfect for short, one-time-use functions!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Smart pointers automatically free memory when done.

Like an auto-return library book system - no memory leaks!
sv.cpp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Exception handling lets you deal with errors gracefully.

Like a safety net in a circus - catch errors before they crash!
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
auto lets the compiler automatically determine the type.

auto x = 42;        // int
auto pi = 3.14;     // double
auto name = "Alice"; // const char*
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content:
NULL is actually 0, which can be ambiguous:

void f(int);    // takes int
void f(int*);   // takes pointer

f(NULL);    // Ambiguous!
f(nullptr); // Clearly f(int*)
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
const: value won't change after initialization
constexpr: value is known at compile time

const int a = getValue();     // OK at runtime
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // Must be compile-time
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
{} prevents data loss:

int x = 3.14;   // OK (becomes 3)
int z{3.14};    // Error! Narrowing conversion
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);
// More efficient than: shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content:
array<int, 3> arr = {10, 20, 30};

arr.at(1);   // OK: 20
arr.at(10);  // Error! Out of range
arr[10];     // Undefined behavior (dangerous)
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content:
Capture lets lambdas use external variables.

int x = 10;
auto f = [x]() { return x * 2; };  // Capture by copy
auto g = [&x]() { x++; };           // Capture by reference
sv.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content:
[x]      // Capture x by copy
[&x]     // Capture x by reference
[=]      // Capture all by copy
[&]      // Capture all by reference
[=, &x]  // All by copy, x by reference
sv.cpp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
unique_ptr is an exclusive ownership smart pointer.

Like a movie ticket - only one person can hold it!

auto p = make_unique<int>(42);
cout << *p << endl; // 42
sv.cpp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
variant safely holds one of several types.

variant<int, string> v;
v = 42;        // Now holds int
v = "hello";   // Now holds string
sv.cpp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
Works with any string type, no copying:

void f(string_view sv);  // Recommended!

f(s);        // string
f("hello");  // literal
f(cstr);     // const char*
sv.cpp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
Common exception types:

runtime_error     // Runtime error
logic_error       // Logic error
out_of_range      // Index out of bounds
invalid_argument  // Invalid argument

tr.cpp_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of C++, a powerful extension of C. Master modern features to create versatile programs.
tr.cpp_lesson2_course_description: Learn object-oriented programming with C++ classes. Master inheritance, templates, and smart pointers.
tr.cpp_lesson3_course_description: Learn modern C++ features including smart pointers, move semantics, and STL algorithms.
tr.cpp_lesson4_course_description: Master STL algorithms and C++17 features. Write efficient and expressive code.
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
C++ is a powerful and fast programming language based on C with many additional features.

Like a sports car compared to a regular car - same speed but with more features!

Used in games, browsers (Chrome, Firefox), and 3D graphics software where speed matters.
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are named 'boxes' that store data in your program.

Just like labeling toy boxes 'blocks' or 'dolls', we name variables to know what's inside.
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Computers can calculate much faster than humans.

They never get tired, even with millions of calculations!
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
The % operator gives you the remainder of division.

10 cookies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 left over!
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content:
Use += to add to current value and save it.

int x = 10;
x += 5;  // same as x = x + 5
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 15
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content:
Use -= to subtract and save:

int x = 10;
x -= 3;  // same as x = x - 3
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 7
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: Combine text and variables in a single message using << like train cars connecting together.
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
A dynamic array can grow or shrink as needed.

Like expandable lockers that can add more compartments when needed!
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

'If it rains, bring umbrella'
'If sunny, play outside'
'If score >= 80, get a reward'
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles when the condition isn't met.

Like 'If score >= 80, play games. Otherwise, study.'
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
Combine multiple conditions:

&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Like taking attendance - calling each name one by one.
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
A dictionary (map) stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up a name to get the number!
tr.cpp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Functions package reusable code with a name.

'Morning routine' = wash face + brush teeth + change clothes. Just say 'do morning routine'!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex1_comment1: Use class to define a class
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
A class is a 'blueprint' that bundles data (variables) and functions together.

Like a 'Dog' blueprint with data (name, age) and functions (bark, run).
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
A constructor is a special function that runs automatically when an object is created.

Like initial setup when you buy a new phone!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: Member functions are functions defined inside a class. They can use the class's data.
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: A reference is an alias (another name) for an existing variable.
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets you create a new class based on an existing one.

'Dog' inherits from 'Animal' - gets eat() and sleep() for free!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Override lets you replace a parent class's function in the child class. Use virtual in the parent.
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
Templates let you write generic code that works with any type.

One code works for int, double, string, and more!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions create anonymous functions on the spot.

Perfect for short, one-time-use functions!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Smart pointers automatically free memory when done.

Like an auto-return library book system - no memory leaks!
tr.cpp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Exception handling lets you deal with errors gracefully.

Like a safety net in a circus - catch errors before they crash!
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
auto lets the compiler automatically determine the type.

auto x = 42;        // int
auto pi = 3.14;     // double
auto name = "Alice"; // const char*
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content:
NULL is actually 0, which can be ambiguous:

void f(int);    // takes int
void f(int*);   // takes pointer

f(NULL);    // Ambiguous!
f(nullptr); // Clearly f(int*)
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
const: value won't change after initialization
constexpr: value is known at compile time

const int a = getValue();     // OK at runtime
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // Must be compile-time
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
{} prevents data loss:

int x = 3.14;   // OK (becomes 3)
int z{3.14};    // Error! Narrowing conversion
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);
// More efficient than: shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content:
array<int, 3> arr = {10, 20, 30};

arr.at(1);   // OK: 20
arr.at(10);  // Error! Out of range
arr[10];     // Undefined behavior (dangerous)
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content:
Capture lets lambdas use external variables.

int x = 10;
auto f = [x]() { return x * 2; };  // Capture by copy
auto g = [&x]() { x++; };           // Capture by reference
tr.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content:
[x]      // Capture x by copy
[&x]     // Capture x by reference
[=]      // Capture all by copy
[&]      // Capture all by reference
[=, &x]  // All by copy, x by reference
tr.cpp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
unique_ptr is an exclusive ownership smart pointer.

Like a movie ticket - only one person can hold it!

auto p = make_unique<int>(42);
cout << *p << endl; // 42
tr.cpp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
variant safely holds one of several types.

variant<int, string> v;
v = 42;        // Now holds int
v = "hello";   // Now holds string
tr.cpp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
Works with any string type, no copying:

void f(string_view sv);  // Recommended!

f(s);        // string
f("hello");  // literal
f(cstr);     // const char*
tr.cpp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
Common exception types:

runtime_error     // Runtime error
logic_error       // Logic error
out_of_range      // Index out of bounds
invalid_argument  // Invalid argument

zh-Hans.cpp_lesson4_course_description: Master STL algorithms and C++17 features. Write efficient and expressive code.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
C++ is a powerful and fast programming language based on C with many additional features.

Like a sports car compared to a regular car - same speed but with more features!

Used in games, browsers (Chrome, Firefox), and 3D graphics software where speed matters.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are named 'boxes' that store data in your program.

Just like labeling toy boxes 'blocks' or 'dolls', we name variables to know what's inside.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Computers can calculate much faster than humans.

They never get tired, even with millions of calculations!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
The % operator gives you the remainder of division.

10 cookies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 left over!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content:
Use += to add to current value and save it.

int x = 10;
x += 5;  // same as x = x + 5
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 15
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content:
Use -= to subtract and save:

int x = 10;
x -= 3;  // same as x = x - 3
std::cout << x << std::endl;  // => 7
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: Combine text and variables in a single message using << like train cars connecting together.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
A dynamic array can grow or shrink as needed.

Like expandable lockers that can add more compartments when needed!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

'If it rains, bring umbrella'
'If sunny, play outside'
'If score >= 80, get a reward'
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles when the condition isn't met.

Like 'If score >= 80, play games. Otherwise, study.'
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
Combine multiple conditions:

&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Like taking attendance - calling each name one by one.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
A dictionary (map) stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up a name to get the number!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Functions package reusable code with a name.

'Morning routine' = wash face + brush teeth + change clothes. Just say 'do morning routine'!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex1_comment1: Use class to define a class
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
A class is a 'blueprint' that bundles data (variables) and functions together.

Like a 'Dog' blueprint with data (name, age) and functions (bark, run).
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
A constructor is a special function that runs automatically when an object is created.

Like initial setup when you buy a new phone!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: Member functions are functions defined inside a class. They can use the class's data.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: A reference is an alias (another name) for an existing variable.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets you create a new class based on an existing one.

'Dog' inherits from 'Animal' - gets eat() and sleep() for free!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Override lets you replace a parent class's function in the child class. Use virtual in the parent.
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
Templates let you write generic code that works with any type.

One code works for int, double, string, and more!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions create anonymous functions on the spot.

Perfect for short, one-time-use functions!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Smart pointers automatically free memory when done.

Like an auto-return library book system - no memory leaks!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Exception handling lets you deal with errors gracefully.

Like a safety net in a circus - catch errors before they crash!
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
auto lets the compiler automatically determine the type.

auto x = 42;        // int
auto pi = 3.14;     // double
auto name = "Alice"; // const char*
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content:
NULL is actually 0, which can be ambiguous:

void f(int);    // takes int
void f(int*);   // takes pointer

f(NULL);    // Ambiguous!
f(nullptr); // Clearly f(int*)
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
const: value won't change after initialization
constexpr: value is known at compile time

const int a = getValue();     // OK at runtime
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // Must be compile-time
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
{} prevents data loss:

int x = 3.14;   // OK (becomes 3)
int z{3.14};    // Error! Narrowing conversion
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);
// More efficient than: shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content:
array<int, 3> arr = {10, 20, 30};

arr.at(1);   // OK: 20
arr.at(10);  // Error! Out of range
arr[10];     // Undefined behavior (dangerous)
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content:
Capture lets lambdas use external variables.

int x = 10;
auto f = [x]() { return x * 2; };  // Capture by copy
auto g = [&x]() { x++; };           // Capture by reference
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content:
[x]      // Capture x by copy
[&x]     // Capture x by reference
[=]      // Capture all by copy
[&]      // Capture all by reference
[=, &x]  // All by copy, x by reference
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
unique_ptr is an exclusive ownership smart pointer.

Like a movie ticket - only one person can hold it!

auto p = make_unique<int>(42);
cout << *p << endl; // 42
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
variant safely holds one of several types.

variant<int, string> v;
v = 42;        // Now holds int
v = "hello";   // Now holds string
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
Works with any string type, no copying:

void f(string_view sv);  // Recommended!

f(s);        // string
f("hello");  // literal
f(cstr);     // const char*
zh-Hans.cpp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
Common exception types:

runtime_error     // Runtime error
logic_error       // Logic error
out_of_range      // Index out of bounds
invalid_argument  // Invalid argument

zh-Hant.cpp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions create anonymous functions on the spot.

Perfect for short, one-time-use functions!
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Smart pointers automatically free memory when done.

Like an auto-return library book system - no memory leaks!
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Exception handling lets you deal with errors gracefully.

Like a safety net in a circus - catch errors before they crash!
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
auto lets the compiler automatically determine the type.

auto x = 42;        // int
auto pi = 3.14;     // double
auto name = "Alice"; // const char*
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content:
NULL is actually 0, which can be ambiguous:

void f(int);    // takes int
void f(int*);   // takes pointer

f(NULL);    // Ambiguous!
f(nullptr); // Clearly f(int*)
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
const: value won't change after initialization
constexpr: value is known at compile time

const int a = getValue();     // OK at runtime
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // Must be compile-time
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
{} prevents data loss:

int x = 3.14;   // OK (becomes 3)
int z{3.14};    // Error! Narrowing conversion
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);
// More efficient than: shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content:
array<int, 3> arr = {10, 20, 30};

arr.at(1);   // OK: 20
arr.at(10);  // Error! Out of range
arr[10];     // Undefined behavior (dangerous)
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content:
Capture lets lambdas use external variables.

int x = 10;
auto f = [x]() { return x * 2; };  // Capture by copy
auto g = [&x]() { x++; };           // Capture by reference
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content:
[x]      // Capture x by copy
[&x]     // Capture x by reference
[=]      // Capture all by copy
[&]      // Capture all by reference
[=, &x]  // All by copy, x by reference
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
unique_ptr is an exclusive ownership smart pointer.

Like a movie ticket - only one person can hold it!

auto p = make_unique<int>(42);
cout << *p << endl; // 42
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
variant safely holds one of several types.

variant<int, string> v;
v = 42;        // Now holds int
v = "hello";   // Now holds string
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
Works with any string type, no copying:

void f(string_view sv);  // Recommended!

f(s);        // string
f("hello");  // literal
f(cstr);     // const char*
zh-Hant.cpp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
Common exception types:

runtime_error     // Runtime error
logic_error       // Logic error
out_of_range      // Index out of bounds
invalid_argument  // Invalid argument
